iOS App Store Submission: Complete Guide from Development to Review

Dec 24, 2025
Vibe Sparking

iOS App Store Submission: Complete Guide from Development to Review

Section titled “iOS App Store Submission: Complete Guide from Development to Review”

Submitting an iOS app to the App Store can feel overwhelming for first-time developers. This guide walks you through the entire process, using our MoneyMind app as a real-world example. Whether you’re building with Flutter, SwiftUI, or UIKit, these steps apply to all iOS app submissions.

Overview

Section titled “Overview”

The App Store submission process involves several key stages:

  1. App Preparation - Icon, assets, and build configuration
  2. Certificates & Provisioning - Apple Distribution certificate setup
  3. App Store Connect Setup - App information, pricing, and screenshots
  4. Build Upload - Archive and upload via Xcode
  5. Review Submission - Final checklist and submission

Let’s dive into each step.

Step 1: App Icon Creation

Section titled “Step 1: App Icon Creation”

Your app icon is the first impression users get. Apple has strict requirements:

Icon Specifications

Section titled “Icon Specifications”
  • Size: 1024 × 1024 pixels
  • Format: PNG without transparency
  • Shape: Square (iOS automatically applies corner radius)
  • Safe Zone: Keep critical elements within 600-700px centered area

Generating Icons with AI

Section titled “Generating Icons with AI”

Modern AI tools like ChatGPT and Gemini can help design app icons:

  1. Describe your app’s purpose and brand identity
  2. Request multiple variations
  3. Iterate on the best concepts
  4. Export at 1024×1024px without transparency

Flutter Icon Configuration

Section titled “Flutter Icon Configuration”

For Flutter projects, use flutter_launcher_icons:

Run the icon generator:

Step 2: Apple Distribution Certificate

Section titled “Step 2: Apple Distribution Certificate”

You need an Apple Distribution certificate to submit apps to the App Store.

Certificate Types

Section titled “Certificate Types”
Certificate TypePurposeRecommended
Apple DistributionApp Store, TestFlight, Ad Hoc✅ Yes
iOS DistributionLegacy - being deprecated❌ No
Mac App DistributionMac App Store onlyMac only

Creating a Distribution Certificate

Section titled “Creating a Distribution Certificate”
  1. Open Keychain Access on your Mac
  2. Select Keychain Access > Certificate Assistant > Request a Certificate from a Certificate Authority
  3. Enter your email and select “Saved to disk”
  4. Go to Apple Developer Portal
  5. Navigate to Certificates, Identifiers & Profiles
  6. Click + to create new certificate
  7. Select Apple Distribution
  8. Upload your Certificate Signing Request (CSR)
  9. Download and double-click to install

Pro Tip: Xcode Automatic Signing

Section titled “Pro Tip: Xcode Automatic Signing”

For simpler projects, enable automatic signing in Xcode:

  1. Open your project in Xcode
  2. Select your target
  3. Go to Signing & Capabilities
  4. Check Automatically manage signing
  5. Select your team

Step 3: Build and Upload to App Store Connect

Section titled “Step 3: Build and Upload to App Store Connect”

Archive Your App

Section titled “Archive Your App”
  1. In Xcode, select Product > Archive
  2. Wait for the build to complete
  3. The Organizer window opens automatically

Upload to App Store Connect

Section titled “Upload to App Store Connect”
  1. In the Organizer, select your archive
  2. Click Distribute App
  3. Select App Store Connect
  4. Choose Upload
  5. Follow the prompts

Build Processing

Section titled “Build Processing”

After uploading:

  • Apple processes your build (5-30 minutes)
  • You’ll receive an email when processing completes
  • Check for any issues in App Store Connect

Important: Check your email regularly! Apple may flag issues that prevent your build from appearing in App Store Connect.

Step 4: App Store Connect Configuration

Section titled “Step 4: App Store Connect Configuration”

App Information

Section titled “App Information”

Fill in essential details:

  • Name: MoneyMind 省钱思维
  • Subtitle: 帮助你 制定省钱目标、记录每日省钱行动
  • Category: Finance (Primary), Lifestyle (Secondary)

Privacy Policy & Terms of Service

Section titled “Privacy Policy & Terms of Service”

Apple requires privacy policy and terms of service URLs:

  1. Create privacy policy and terms documents
  2. Host them on a publicly accessible URL
  3. Enter URLs in App Store Connect

We host our documents on our website:

  • Privacy Policy: https://yoursite.com/privacy
  • Terms of Service: https://yoursite.com/terms

Pricing and Availability

Section titled “Pricing and Availability”

Configure your app’s pricing:

  • Select price tier or choose “Free”
  • Choose availability by country/region
  • Set pre-order options if desired

Age Rating

Section titled “Age Rating”

Complete the age rating questionnaire:

  • Answer honestly about app content
  • Categories include violence, gambling, mature themes
  • Your rating is automatically calculated

Content Rights

Section titled “Content Rights”

Declare if your app contains, shows, or accesses third-party content.

Step 5: App Privacy Configuration

Section titled “Step 5: App Privacy Configuration”

App Encryption Documentation

Section titled “App Encryption Documentation”

If your app doesn’t use encryption (or only uses exempt encryption), add this to Info.plist:

This prevents Apple from asking about encryption compliance on each submission.

Photo Library Usage

Section titled “Photo Library Usage”

If your app accesses the photo library, add:

Step 6: Screenshots

Section titled “Step 6: Screenshots”

Screenshots are crucial for App Store presence. You need them for multiple device sizes.

iPhone Screenshots

Section titled “iPhone Screenshots”
  • Required Size: 1242 × 2678 pixels (6.7” display)
  • Preparation: Remove top status bar (approximately 100px)
  • Count: 1-10 screenshots

iPad Screenshots

Section titled “iPad Screenshots”
  • Required Size: 2064 × 2752 pixels (12.9” display)
  • Preparation: Remove top status bar (approximately 36px)
  • Count: 1-10 screenshots

Screenshot Tips

Section titled “Screenshot Tips”
  1. Show key features - Highlight your app’s best functionality
  2. Add captions - Brief text explaining each screen
  3. Use device frames - Optional but professional-looking
  4. Maintain consistency - Same style across all screenshots
  5. Localize - Different screenshots for different languages

Step 7: Localization (i18n)

Section titled “Step 7: Localization (i18n)”

App Store Connect supports multiple languages:

  1. Go to App Information
  2. Click + next to your primary language
  3. Add supported languages
  4. Fill in localized:
    • App name
    • Subtitle
    • Description
    • Keywords
    • Screenshots

Key Languages to Consider

Section titled “Key Languages to Consider”
  • English (US/UK)
  • Simplified Chinese
  • Japanese
  • Korean
  • German
  • French
  • Spanish

Step 8: Submit for Review

Section titled “Step 8: Submit for Review”

Pre-Submission Checklist

Section titled “Pre-Submission Checklist”
  • App icon uploaded
  • Screenshots for all device sizes
  • Privacy policy URL working
  • Terms of service URL working
  • App description complete
  • Keywords optimized
  • Age rating completed
  • Build uploaded and processed
  • Build selected in App Store Connect
  • Contact information accurate

Submit

Section titled “Submit”
  1. Navigate to your app in App Store Connect
  2. Select your app version
  3. Click Submit for Review
  4. Answer review questions
  5. Confirm submission

Review Timeline

Section titled “Review Timeline”
  • Initial Review: Usually 24-48 hours
  • Rejection Response: Typically within 24 hours of resubmission
  • Expedited Reviews: Available for critical issues

Common Rejection Reasons & Solutions

Section titled “Common Rejection Reasons & Solutions”

1. Guideline 2.1 - App Completeness

Section titled “1. Guideline 2.1 - App Completeness”

Issue: App crashes, has placeholder content, or incomplete features.

Solution: Thoroughly test before submission. Remove any TODO or placeholder text.

2. Guideline 2.3 - Accurate Metadata

Section titled “2. Guideline 2.3 - Accurate Metadata”

Issue: Screenshots don’t match actual app, misleading descriptions.

Solution: Update screenshots after every major UI change.

3. Guideline 5.1.1 - Data Collection and Storage

Section titled “3. Guideline 5.1.1 - Data Collection and Storage”

Issue: Missing privacy policy or improper data handling disclosure.

Solution: Create comprehensive privacy policy, declare all data collection in App Store Connect.

4. Guideline 4.2 - Minimum Functionality

Section titled “4. Guideline 4.2 - Minimum Functionality”

Issue: App is too simple or doesn’t provide enough value.

Solution: Ensure your app provides meaningful functionality beyond what a website could offer.

Tips for Success

Section titled “Tips for Success”

1. Test on Real Devices

Section titled “1. Test on Real Devices”

Simulator testing isn’t enough. Test on:

  • Multiple iPhone models
  • iPads (if universal app)
  • Oldest supported iOS version

2. Monitor Email

Section titled “2. Monitor Email”

Apple communicates via email for:

  • Build processing issues
  • Review status updates
  • Rejection reasons
  • App approval notifications

3. Respond Quickly to Rejections

Section titled “3. Respond Quickly to Rejections”

Fast, professional responses to rejections:

  • Show Apple you’re engaged
  • Address all points raised
  • Ask for clarification if needed

4. Keep TestFlight Active

Section titled “4. Keep TestFlight Active”

Use TestFlight for:

  • Beta testing before submission
  • Quick iteration on fixes
  • User feedback collection

5. Plan for Review Time

Section titled “5. Plan for Review Time”

Don’t submit at the last minute:

  • Allow 1-2 weeks buffer for reviews
  • Account for potential rejections
  • Holiday periods may have longer queues

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

Submitting to the App Store requires attention to detail and patience. By following this guide and preparing thoroughly, you can navigate the process smoothly and get your app into users’ hands.

Key takeaways:

  1. Prepare assets early - Icon, screenshots, and metadata take time
  2. Test thoroughly - Real device testing prevents rejections
  3. Read guidelines - Apple’s guidelines evolve; stay updated
  4. Be responsive - Quick responses to Apple expedite reviews
  5. Monitor communications - Email is your lifeline to Apple

Good luck with your App Store submission!

Have questions about iOS development? Check out our other guides on Flutter development and mobile app best practices.

  • App Store Connect
  • Mobile Development
  • Apple

Google Code Wiki: AI-Powered Documentation That Evolves With Your Code

Dec 23, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Google Code Wiki: AI-Powered Documentation That Evolves With Your Code

Section titled “Google Code Wiki: AI-Powered Documentation That Evolves With Your Code”

In November 2025, Google introduced Code Wiki, a revolutionary platform that addresses one of software development’s most persistent challenges: keeping documentation synchronized with code. Powered by Gemini AI, Code Wiki automatically generates and maintains comprehensive, always-up-to-date documentation for any code repository.

What is Google Code Wiki?

Section titled “What is Google Code Wiki?”

Code Wiki is a new platform designed for the agentic era of software development. It maintains a continuously updated, structured wiki for code repositories, automatically regenerating documentation after every code change.

“A new perspective on development for the agentic era. Gemini-generated documentation, always up-to-date.”

The Documentation Problem

Section titled “The Documentation Problem”

Reading and understanding existing code is one of the biggest, most expensive bottlenecks in software development. Traditional documentation:

  • Gets outdated quickly - Code changes faster than docs can be updated
  • Lacks context - Static docs don’t explain relationships between components
  • Requires manual effort - Engineers spend time writing docs instead of coding
  • Becomes inconsistent - Different authors, different styles, incomplete coverage

Code Wiki solves these problems through automated, AI-powered documentation generation.

Core Features & Highlights

Section titled “Core Features & Highlights”

1. Automatic Documentation Generation

Section titled “1. Automatic Documentation Generation”

Code Wiki scans entire repositories and generates structured documentation automatically:

  • Full codebase analysis - Understands all files, functions, and relationships
  • Regeneration on every commit - Docs update automatically with each change
  • Architecture diagrams - Visual representations generated and kept current
  • Class and sequence diagrams - Technical visualizations for complex systems

2. Gemini-Powered Chat Interface

Section titled “2. Gemini-Powered Chat Interface”

Each Code Wiki page includes an intelligent chat agent:

  • Context-aware Q&A - Ask specific questions about YOUR codebase
  • Full wiki knowledge - Chat uses the complete, current documentation as context
  • Direct code links - Answers include hyperlinks to relevant source files
  • Natural language queries - Ask questions in plain English

Example interactions:

  • “How does the authentication module work?”
  • “What functions call the database connection pool?”
  • “Explain the data flow in the payment processing system”

3. Hyperlinked Navigation

Section titled “3. Hyperlinked Navigation”

Every documentation element connects directly to source code:

  • Symbol linking - Click any function, class, or variable to see its definition
  • Cross-references - Navigate between related concepts seamlessly
  • File locations - Know exactly where code lives
  • Definition chains - Trace from high-level concepts to implementation details

4. Powered by NotebookLM

Section titled “4. Powered by NotebookLM”

Code Wiki integrates with Google’s NotebookLM for enhanced documentation:

  • Video explanations - Auto-generated video walkthroughs of codebases
  • Interactive presentations - Architecture overviews with multimedia
  • Audio summaries - Listen to code explanations (coming soon)

Prerequisites & Getting Started

Section titled “Prerequisites & Getting Started”

Accessing Code Wiki

Section titled “Accessing Code Wiki”

Public Preview (Available Now):

  1. Visit codewiki.google
  2. Search for any public open-source repository
  3. Code Wiki generates documentation automatically

Supported Repositories:

  • GitHub public repositories
  • GitLab public projects
  • Bitbucket public repos

Featured Repositories

Section titled “Featured Repositories”

Code Wiki showcases documentation for popular projects:

RepositoryStarsDescription

Auto-Claude: Autonomous Multi-Session AI Coding That 10x Your Development Output

Dec 22, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Introduction

Section titled “Introduction”

Auto-Claude is a revolutionary desktop application created by AndyMik90 that transforms how developers interact with AI coding assistants. Unlike traditional single-session AI coding tools, Auto-Claude enables you to run up to 12 parallel Claude Code terminals simultaneously, each working on different tasks while maintaining complete isolation through git worktrees.

Whether you’re a “vibe coder” just getting started or an experienced developer managing complex projects, Auto-Claude meets you where you are with autonomous agents that plan, code, and validate for you.

Key Highlights

Section titled “Key Highlights”
  • 10x Development Output: Run multiple builds simultaneously while maintaining code quality
  • 12 Parallel Agent Terminals: Clean layout with smart naming and one-click context injection
  • Git Worktree Isolation: All work happens safely without disturbing your main branch
  • Self-Validating QA: Built-in agents check their own work before you review
  • Cross-Session Memory: Agents remember insights across sessions using FalkorDB graph database
  • AI Merge Resolution: Intelligent conflict resolution when merging back to main
  • Cross-Platform: Desktop app runs on Mac, Windows, and Linux

Prerequisites

Section titled “Prerequisites”

Before installing Auto-Claude, ensure you have the following components:

RequirementVersionPurpose
Node.js18+Desktop UI runtime
Python3.10+Backend agent execution
Docker DesktopLatestMemory Layer (FalkorDB)
Claude Code CLILatestAI coding engine
Claude SubscriptionPro or MaxRequired for Claude Code access
Git Repository-Worktree isolation

Git Initialization

Section titled “Git Initialization”

Auto-Claude requires a git repository to create isolated worktrees for safe parallel development:

Git worktrees allow you to work on multiple features simultaneously without conflicts, keeping your main branch clean until you’re ready to merge.

  4. Restart terminal and run npm install again

Core Features

Section titled “Core Features”

1. Kanban Board Interface

Section titled “1. Kanban Board Interface”

Plan tasks and let AI handle planning, coding, and validation in a visual interface. Track progress from “Planning” to “Done” while agents work autonomously.

2. Agent Terminals

Section titled “2. Agent Terminals”

Spawn up to 12 AI-powered terminals for hands-on coding:

  • Inject task context with a click
  • Reference files from your project
  • Work rapidly across multiple sessions
  • Connect multiple Claude Code subscriptions for teams

3. Three-Phase Agent Pipeline

Section titled “3. Three-Phase Agent Pipeline”

Phase 1: Spec Creation (3-8 phases)

  • Discovery — Analyzes project structure and tech stack
  • Requirements — Gathers requirements through interactive conversation
  • Research — Validates external integrations against real documentation
  • Context Discovery — Finds relevant files in your codebase
  • Spec Writer — Creates comprehensive specification document
  • Spec Critic — Self-critiques using extended thinking
  • Planner — Breaks work into subtasks with dependencies
  • Validation — Ensures all outputs are valid

Phase 2: Implementation

  • Planner Agent creates subtask-based implementation plan
  • Coder Agent implements subtasks one-by-one with verification
  • QA Reviewer validates all acceptance criteria
  • QA Fixer fixes issues in a self-healing loop (up to 50 iterations)

Phase 3: Merge

  • Conflict Detection identifies modified files
  • 3-Tier Resolution: Git auto-merge → Conflict-only AI → Full-file AI
  • Parallel Merge for multiple files simultaneously
  • Staged for Review before finalizing

4. Memory Layer Architecture

Section titled “4. Memory Layer Architecture”

The Memory Layer combines graph nodes with semantic search:

SetupLLMEmbeddingsNotes
OpenAIOpenAIOpenAISimplest - single API key
Anthropic + VoyageAnthropicVoyage AIHigh quality
Google AIGeminiGoogleFast inference
OllamaOllamaOllamaFully offline
AzureAzure OpenAIAzure OpenAIEnterprise

5. Security Model

Section titled “5. Security Model”

Three-layer defense keeps your code safe:

  • OS Sandbox: Bash commands run in isolation
  • Filesystem Restrictions: Operations limited to project directory
  • Command Allowlist: Only approved commands based on your project’s stack

  • Shared Memory Layer preserves project context

Best Practices

Section titled “Best Practices”

  1. Start with Clear Specifications: Provide detailed task descriptions for better agent performance

  2. Use Git Worktrees: Let Auto-Claude manage isolation - never work directly on main during builds

  3. Review QA Reports: Check the self-validation results before accepting changes

  4. Leverage Memory Layer: Enable FalkorDB for better context across sessions

  5. Batch Similar Tasks: Group related work to maximize parallel efficiency

  6. Monitor Resource Usage: 12 parallel agents can be resource-intensive - adjust based on your hardware

Precautions and FAQ

Section titled “Precautions and FAQ”

Precautions

Section titled “Precautions”
  1. Claude Subscription Required: You need Claude Pro or Max for Claude Code access
  2. Resource Intensive: Running 12 parallel agents requires significant CPU/RAM
  3. Docker Dependency: Memory Layer requires Docker Desktop running
  4. AGPL-3.0 License: Commercial use requires open-sourcing your modifications

FAQ

Section titled “FAQ”

Q: How is Auto-Claude different from regular Claude Code? A: Auto-Claude wraps Claude Code with parallel execution, git worktree isolation, self-validating QA, and cross-session memory. It’s a productivity multiplier, not a replacement.

Q: Can I use this with my existing project? A: Yes! Just ensure your project is a git repository. Auto-Claude creates isolated worktrees without modifying your main branch.

Q: How many agents should I run? A: Start with 2-4 and scale up based on your hardware. Each agent consumes Claude Code API credits separately.

Q: Does it work offline? A: The Memory Layer supports Ollama for fully offline operation, but Claude Code requires internet connectivity.

Q: What happens if an agent gets stuck? A: The QA Fixer runs up to 50 iterations in a self-healing loop. If it still fails, you can review and intervene manually.

Enabling Claude Code to Work More Autonomously: Complete Guide to VS Code Extension, Checkpoints & Agent SDK

Dec 22, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Introduction

Section titled “Introduction”

Anthropic has released several major upgrades to Claude Code that fundamentally transform how developers interact with AI-powered development tools. These updates include a native VS Code extension, version 2.0 of the terminal interface, and most notably, checkpoints for autonomous operation. Powered by Claude Sonnet 4.5, Claude Code now handles longer, more complex development tasks with unprecedented confidence and control.

This article provides a comprehensive guide to these new autonomy features, covering installation, configuration, best practices, and real-world workflow examples.

Key Features and Highlights

Section titled “Key Features and Highlights”

1. Native VS Code Extension (Beta)

Section titled “1. Native VS Code Extension (Beta)”

The native VS Code extension brings Claude Code directly into your IDE with several powerful capabilities:

  • Real-time Change Visualization: See Claude’s changes in real-time through a dedicated sidebar panel with inline diffs
  • Graphical Experience: A richer, more visual Claude Code experience for developers who prefer IDEs over terminals
  • Seamless Integration: Works within your existing VS Code workflow without context switching

Installation: Download from the VS Code Extension Marketplace

2. Enhanced Terminal Experience (v2.0)

Section titled “2. Enhanced Terminal Experience (v2.0)”

The refreshed terminal interface includes:

  • Improved Status Visibility: Better visual feedback on Claude’s current operations
  • Searchable Prompt History: Use Ctrl+r to search and reuse previous prompts
  • Streamlined UX: Easier navigation and command execution

3. Checkpoints System

Section titled “3. Checkpoints System”

The checkpoint system is a game-changer for autonomous development:

  • Automatic State Saving: Automatically saves your code state before each change
  • Instant Rewind: Tap Esc twice or use /rewind command to return to previous versions
  • Selective Restoration: Choose to restore code, conversation, or both
  • Multi-level Undo: Not just one level—checkpoints are kept for each change

Best Practice: Use checkpoints in combination with version control (git) for maximum safety.

4. Subagents for Parallel Development

Section titled “4. Subagents for Parallel Development”

Subagents delegate specialized tasks, enabling parallel development workflows:

5. Hooks for Automated Workflows

Section titled “5. Hooks for Automated Workflows”

Hooks trigger actions at specific points in the development lifecycle:

  • PostToolUse: Run tests after code changes
  • PreToolUse: Lint before commits
  • SessionStart/End: Initialize or cleanup resources
  • UserPromptSubmit: Validate or transform user input

6. Background Tasks

Section titled “6. Background Tasks”

Keep long-running processes active without blocking progress:

  • Dev servers running continuously
  • Build watchers monitoring changes
  • Database migrations running in background
  • Compilation tasks executing asynchronously

System Requirements

Section titled “System Requirements”

  • Python: Version 3.10 or higher (for Python SDK)
  • Operating System: macOS, Linux, or Windows with WSL

Precautions and FAQ

Safety Considerations

Section titled “Safety Considerations”

  1. Checkpoints vs Git: Checkpoints only track Claude’s edits, not user edits or bash commands. Always use git for version control.

  2. Subagent Permissions: Be careful about which tools you grant to subagents. Use principle of least privilege.

  3. Background Tasks: Monitor background tasks to prevent resource exhaustion.

Frequently Asked Questions

Section titled “Frequently Asked Questions”

Q: Can I use checkpoints without git? A: Yes, but it’s not recommended. Checkpoints supplement, not replace, version control.

Q: How many subagents can run in parallel? A: There’s no hard limit, but resource constraints apply. Start with 2-3 and scale based on your system.

Q: Do hooks slow down development? A: Minimal overhead. Hooks run asynchronously where possible.

Q: Can I use Claude Code with local models? A: The Agent SDK supports Bedrock, Vertex AI, and Foundry. Local model support depends on provider compatibility.

Fabric: The Open-Source Framework for Augmenting Humans Using AI

Dec 22, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Fabric: The Open-Source Framework for Augmenting Humans Using AI

Section titled “Fabric: The Open-Source Framework for Augmenting Humans Using AI”

In the rapidly evolving landscape of AI tools, Fabric stands out as a revolutionary open-source framework designed to bridge the gap between AI capabilities and human integration. Created by security researcher and AI enthusiast Daniel Miessler, Fabric addresses a fundamental problem: AI doesn’t have a capabilities problem—it has an integration problem.

What is Fabric?

Section titled “What is Fabric?”

Fabric is an open-source framework that organizes and manages AI prompts—called Patterns—in a modular, reusable system. Unlike scattered prompts across various tools and platforms, Fabric provides a centralized, command-line-first approach to collecting, organizing, and executing AI solutions.

The Philosophy Behind Fabric

Section titled “The Philosophy Behind Fabric”

“AI isn’t a thing; it’s a magnifier of a thing. And that thing is human creativity.”

Fabric’s philosophy centers on breaking complex problems into manageable components and applying AI to each piece systematically. This approach transforms AI from a mysterious black box into a practical, everyday tool.

Key Features and Highlights

Section titled “Key Features and Highlights”

1. Pattern-Based Architecture

Section titled “1. Pattern-Based Architecture”

Patterns are the core building blocks of Fabric. Each Pattern is a carefully crafted prompt designed for a specific real-world task:

  • extract_wisdom: Extract key insights from YouTube videos and podcasts
  • summarize: Create concise summaries of any content
  • analyze_claims: Evaluate claims for accuracy and validity
  • write_essay: Generate essays in your own voice
  • create_coding_feature: Generate code features with context
  • improve_writing: Enhance writing quality and clarity

With over 150+ built-in Patterns, Fabric covers diverse use cases from content creation to code analysis.

2. Multi-Model Support

Section titled “2. Multi-Model Support”

Fabric supports an impressive array of AI providers:

  • OpenAI (GPT-4, GPT-4o, o1, o3)
  • Anthropic (Claude 4, Claude 4.5 Opus)
  • Google (Gemini)
  • Local models via Ollama
  • Azure OpenAI
  • Amazon Bedrock
  • Perplexity AI
  • Venice AI (privacy-focused)
  • Together AI
  • And many more…

3. Seamless CLI Integration

Section titled “3. Seamless CLI Integration”

Fabric is built for the command line, making it perfect for developers and power users:

4. Context and Session Management

Section titled “4. Context and Session Management”

Fabric supports persistent contexts and sessions:

  • Contexts: Pre-created background information added to all queries
  • Sessions: Maintain conversation history across multiple interactions
  • Variables: Dynamic pattern customization with {{variable}} syntax

5. REST API Server

Section titled “5. REST API Server”

Fabric includes a built-in REST API server for integration with other applications:

Features include:

  • Chat completions with streaming
  • Pattern management (CRUD operations)
  • YouTube transcript extraction
  • Swagger/OpenAPI documentation

6. Web Interface

Section titled “6. Web Interface”

A GUI alternative to the CLI is available for those who prefer visual interfaces, providing access to all Fabric functionality through a web browser.

Prerequisites

Section titled “Prerequisites”

Before installing Fabric, ensure you have:

  • Go 1.22+ (for source installation)
  • API keys for your preferred AI providers (OpenAI, Anthropic, etc.)
  • yt-dlp (optional, for YouTube transcript extraction)
  • LaTeX distribution (optional, for PDF generation with to_pdf)

FAQ

Section titled “FAQ”

Q: Is Fabric free to use? A: Yes, Fabric is MIT licensed. However, you need API keys for AI providers, which may have costs.

Q: Can I use Fabric without internet? A: Yes, with local models through Ollama.

Q: How do I contribute patterns? A: Submit a pull request to the Fabric repository with your pattern in the data/patterns directory.

Q: Does Fabric store my data? A: Fabric processes data locally. Data is sent to AI providers based on your configuration.

Q: Can I use multiple models in one workflow? A: Yes, you can chain patterns with different models using shell pipes.

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

Fabric represents a paradigm shift in how we interact with AI. By providing a structured, modular, and command-line-friendly framework, it transforms AI from an occasional tool into an integrated part of our daily workflows. Whether you’re a developer, content creator, security researcher, or knowledge worker, Fabric’s pattern-based approach offers a powerful way to augment your capabilities with AI.

The project’s active development, growing community, and extensive pattern library make it an essential tool for anyone serious about leveraging AI effectively. Start with the basic patterns, explore the community contributions, and eventually create your own—that’s the path to truly augmented human productivity.

This article was researched and written with assistance from AI tools, demonstrating the very integration that Fabric enables.

PromptHub: Open-Source Local-First AI Prompt Management Tool

Dec 22, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Introduction

Section titled “Introduction”

Are you tired of searching through notebooks, documents, and chat histories to find your AI prompts? PromptHub solves this problem elegantly - it lets you manage prompts like code with version control, variable templates, and multi-model testing, while keeping all your data stored locally for maximum privacy.

PromptHub is an open-source, free AI prompt management tool developed by legeling. Built with Electron, React, and TypeScript, it provides a modern desktop experience across macOS, Windows, and Linux platforms.

Key Features and Highlights

Section titled “Key Features and Highlights”

Comprehensive Prompt Management

Section titled “Comprehensive Prompt Management”

PromptHub offers a complete suite for organizing your AI prompts:

  • Create, Edit, and Delete - Full CRUD operations with intuitive interface
  • Folder and Tag System - Organize prompts with hierarchical folders and customizable tags
  • Favorites - Quick access to frequently used prompts
  • Full-Text Search - Search across titles, descriptions, and content
  • Multiple View Modes - Card, Gallery, and List views for different workflows

Version Control

Section titled “Version Control”

Never lose a good prompt again:

  • Automatic History - Every edit is automatically saved
  • Version Comparison - Side-by-side diff view for changes
  • Rollback Support - Restore any previous version with one click

Variable Templates

Section titled “Variable Templates”

Make your prompts dynamic and reusable:

When copying or testing, PromptHub prompts you to fill in the variables, making templates infinitely reusable.

Multi-Model AI Testing

Section titled “Multi-Model AI Testing”

Test your prompts across different AI models:

  • 18+ Providers Supported - OpenAI, Claude, Gemini, DeepSeek, Qwen, and more
  • Parallel Testing - Compare responses from multiple models simultaneously
  • Image Generation - Support for DALL-E and Stability AI
  • Result Persistence - Save test results with each prompt

Data Security and Privacy

Section titled “Data Security and Privacy”

Your data stays yours:

  • Local-First Storage - All data stored in local SQLite database
  • Master Password Protection - Application-level security
  • Private Folders - Encrypted storage for sensitive prompts (Beta)
  • Full Backup/Restore - Export everything in .phub.gz format
  • WebDAV Sync - Optional cloud sync with services like Nextcloud

Prerequisites and Installation

Section titled “Prerequisites and Installation”

System Requirements

Section titled “System Requirements”

PromptHub runs on:

  • macOS - Intel and Apple Silicon (M1/M2/M3/M4)
  • Windows - x64 architecture
  • Linux - x64 (AppImage and .deb formats)

Download and Install

Section titled “Download and Install”

Download the latest release from GitHub Releases:

PlatformArchitectureFormat
Windowsx64.exe installer
macOSApple Silicon.dmg image
macOSIntel.dmg image
Linuxx64.AppImage / .deb

macOS First Launch

Section titled “macOS First Launch”

Due to unsigned code, macOS may show security warnings. Run this command in Terminal:

Or go to System Settings > Privacy & Security > Click “Open Anyway”.

Build From Source

Section titled “Build From Source”

Recommended Usage Scenarios

Section titled “Recommended Usage Scenarios”

Daily Workflow for AI Professionals

Section titled “Daily Workflow for AI Professionals”

Morning Setup:

  1. Open PromptHub with your master password
  2. Review favorites for quick access to common prompts
  3. Use search to find specific prompts by context

During Work:

  1. Create new prompts as you develop them
  2. Use variable templates for repetitive tasks
  3. Test prompts across models before finalizing
  4. Tag and categorize for future retrieval

End of Day:

  1. Review version history for any changes
  2. Sync to WebDAV for backup
  3. Export important prompts for sharing

Use Cases

Section titled “Use Cases”
ScenarioHow PromptHub Helps
Content CreationStore writing prompts with style variables
Code GenerationManage coding templates with language/framework variables
Translation WorkTemplate prompts with source/target language placeholders
Research AnalysisCompare AI responses across models
Customer SupportStandardize response templates with personalization

Best Practices

Section titled “Best Practices”
  1. Organize Early - Set up folder structure before adding many prompts
  2. Use Meaningful Tags - Tags like production, experimental, deprecated
  3. Template Variables - Make prompts reusable with {{variable}} syntax
  4. Regular Backups - Enable WebDAV sync or manual exports
  5. Version Notes - Add descriptions when making significant changes

Precautions and Troubleshooting

Section titled “Precautions and Troubleshooting”

Common Issues

Section titled “Common Issues”

Application Won’t Start on macOS:

  • Run the xattr command mentioned in installation
  • Check System Settings > Privacy & Security

Database Corruption:

  • Use the backup feature regularly
  • Keep the .phub.gz backup file safe
  • Restore from backup if needed

AI Testing Fails:

  • Verify API key is correct
  • Check API endpoint URL
  • Ensure model name matches provider’s specification

WebDAV Sync Issues:

  • Verify WebDAV URL ends with correct path
  • Test connection in settings before enabling auto-sync
  • Check firewall/proxy settings

FAQ

Section titled “FAQ”

Q: Is my data sent to any cloud service? A: No, all data is stored locally. WebDAV sync is optional and user-controlled.

Q: Can I share prompts with colleagues? A: Yes, export individual prompts or full backups in .phub.gz format.

Q: What happens if I forget my master password? A: Unfortunately, encrypted data cannot be recovered without the password.

Q: Does it work offline? A: The prompt management features work fully offline. Only AI testing requires internet.

Desktop Commander MCP: Transform Claude into Your Ultimate AI Development Partner

Dec 22, 2025

Desktop Commander MCP: Transform Claude into Your Ultimate AI Development Partner

Section titled “Desktop Commander MCP: Transform Claude into Your Ultimate AI Development Partner”

Introduction

Section titled “Introduction”

What if your AI assistant could not only understand your code but also execute commands, manage files, and work across your entire operating system? Desktop Commander MCP makes this possible, transforming Claude Desktop into a powerful, autonomous development partner that goes far beyond traditional IDE-focused AI tools.

Created by Eduard Ruzga (wonderwhy-er), Desktop Commander MCP is a Model Context Protocol (MCP) server that bridges Claude Desktop with your local system. With over thousands of weekly npm downloads and a growing community of enthusiastic developers, it’s rapidly becoming the go-to solution for developers who want AI-assisted development without the fragmentation of multiple tools.

Key Features and Highlights

Section titled “Key Features and Highlights”

🚀 Enhanced Terminal Control

Section titled “🚀 Enhanced Terminal Control”

Desktop Commander provides intelligent terminal integration with:

  • Smart process detection - Automatically knows when programs are ready for input
  • Interactive session management - Maintain long-running sessions (SSH, databases, dev servers)
  • Background execution - Run commands with timeout support
  • Process control - List, monitor, and terminate processes

📁 Comprehensive File Operations

Section titled “📁 Comprehensive File Operations”
  • Full filesystem access with intelligent permissions
  • Native Excel support (.xlsx, .xls, .xlsm) - read, write, edit, search
  • PDF capabilities - Extract text, create from markdown, modify existing PDFs
  • Surgical code editing - Search/replace blocks for precise changes
  • Pattern-based replacements with vscode-ripgrep integration
  • URL support - Fetch content from web resources directly

💻 In-Memory Code Execution

Section titled “💻 In-Memory Code Execution”

Execute code without saving files:

🔧 Configuration Management

Section titled “🔧 Configuration Management”

Dynamic runtime configuration:

  • Blocked commands for security
  • Shell preferences (bash, zsh, PowerShell)
  • Directory access controls
  • File read/write limits

Prerequisites and Installation

Section titled “Prerequisites and Installation”

System Requirements

Section titled “System Requirements”
  • Node.js (v16 or higher recommended)
  • Claude Desktop application
  • Operating System: macOS, Windows, or Linux

Installation Options

Section titled “Installation Options”

Option 1: NPX (Recommended - Auto-Updates)

Section titled “Option 1: NPX (Recommended - Auto-Updates)”

Section titled “Option 2: macOS Bash Script”

Section titled “Option 3: Docker (Complete Isolation)”

Option 4: Manual Configuration

Section titled “Option 4: Manual Configuration”

Add to your claude_desktop_config.json:

Config locations:

  • macOS: ~/Library/Application Support/Claude/claude_desktop_config.json
  • Windows: %APPDATA%\Claude\claude_desktop_config.json
  • Linux: ~/.config/Claude/claude_desktop_config.json

Recommended Scenarios and Daily Workflow

Section titled “Recommended Scenarios and Daily Workflow”

1. Codebase Exploration and Documentation

Section titled “1. Codebase Exploration and Documentation”

Section titled “2. Multi-Project Development”

  • Work across multiple repositories simultaneously
  • Compare implementations between projects
  • Copy patterns from one project to another

Section titled “3. Automated DevOps Tasks”

4. Data Analysis

Section titled “4. Data Analysis”

Section titled “5. Interactive Development Environments”

Best Practices

Section titled “Best Practices”

Security-First Configuration

Section titled “Security-First Configuration”
  1. Use dedicated configuration chats - Make config changes in separate conversations
  2. Set specific allowedDirectories - Limit filesystem access to needed paths
  3. Review blockedCommands - Prevent dangerous command execution
  4. Consider Docker for sensitive work - Complete isolation from host system

Efficient File Editing

Section titled “Efficient File Editing”

The edit_block tool uses search/replace blocks for surgical edits:

Pro Tips:

  • Make multiple small edits instead of large rewrites
  • Keep fileWriteLineLimit small to encourage efficient behavior
  • Use fuzzy search logs for debugging match failures

Session Management

Section titled “Session Management”

For long-running operations:

  1. Use start_process with smart ready detection
  2. Interact via interact_with_process
  3. Monitor with read_process_output
  4. Clean up with force_terminate

Precautions and Troubleshooting

Section titled “Precautions and Troubleshooting”

Known Limitations

Section titled “Known Limitations”
  1. Directory restrictions can be bypassed - Security through allowedDirectories is not absolute
  2. Terminal commands unrestricted - allowedDirectories only affects file operations
  3. File write limits - Default 50 lines per write to encourage efficient AI behavior

Common Issues

Section titled “Common Issues”

Claude times out:

  • Ensure MCP server is running
  • Check config JSON syntax
  • Restart Claude Desktop

Commands fail:

  • Verify shell path in configuration
  • Check command isn’t in blockedCommands
  • Ensure proper permissions

File access denied:

  • Add path to allowedDirectories
  • Verify file permissions on disk

Debug Mode

Section titled “Debug Mode”

For troubleshooting:

Connect debugger to Node.js process on port 9229.

FAQ

Section titled “FAQ”

Q: Do I need API credits? A: No. Works with Claude Desktop Pro subscription ($20/month), not API calls.

Q: Does it auto-update? A: Yes, when installed via npx or Smithery, updates apply on Claude restart.

Q: Is my data collected? A: Limited pseudonymous telemetry only. No file contents or paths. Opt-out available.

Q: Can I use it with other Claude clients? A: Designed for Claude Desktop. Community adapters may exist for other clients.

Whether you’re exploring unfamiliar codebases, automating DevOps tasks, or building new features, Desktop Commander puts all your development tools in one intelligent chat interface.

The solution-centric approach—working with your entire OS rather than a single IDE workspace—combined with the cost efficiency of subscription-based pricing, makes it an compelling alternative to fragmented, API-token-hungry alternatives.

Ready to supercharge your development workflow? Install Desktop Commander and experience the future of AI-assisted development today.

Desktop Commander MCP: Terminal Control & File System Access for Claude

Desktop Commander MCP: Terminal Control & File System Access for Claude

Section titled “Desktop Commander MCP: Terminal Control & File System Access for Claude”

In the rapidly evolving AI development landscape, Desktop Commander MCP stands out as a game-changing tool that transforms Claude Desktop into a powerful desktop automation assistant. Unlike traditional IDE-focused tools, Desktop Commander provides a solution-centric approach that works with your entire operating system.

What is Desktop Commander MCP?

Section titled “What is Desktop Commander MCP?”

Desktop Commander MCP is an open-source MCP (Model Context Protocol) server created by wonderwhy-er that enables Claude to:

  • Execute terminal commands with output streaming
  • Search and manage file systems
  • Edit files with surgical precision using diff capabilities
  • Read and write Excel, PDF, and various data files
  • Run code in memory without file persistence

“Work with code and text, run processes and automate tasks beyond typical AI editor limitations.”

Key Features & Highlights

Section titled “Key Features & Highlights”

1. Terminal & Process Control

Section titled “1. Terminal & Process Control”

Desktop Commander provides comprehensive terminal management:

Capabilities include:

  • Command execution with configurable timeouts
  • Background process execution
  • Process listing and termination
  • Session management for SSH, databases, and development servers

Excel Support (.xlsx, .xls, .xlsm):

  • Search within Excel files

  • Text extraction from PDF documents

  • Document modification capabilities

  • WSL Support - Windows Subsystem for Linux exploration

Troubleshooting & FAQ

Section titled “Troubleshooting & FAQ”

Q: Commands are timing out

Section titled “Q: Commands are timing out”

A: Increase timeout in configuration or use background execution for long-running tasks.

Q: Permission denied errors

Section titled “Q: Permission denied errors”

A: Check directory access permissions in Desktop Commander configuration.

Q: Docker container not persisting data

Section titled “Q: Docker container not persisting data”

A: Use volume mounts (-v flag) for data persistence.

Q: Can’t find files with search

Section titled “Q: Can’t find files with search”

A: Ensure the search path is within allowed directories and try adjusting the search pattern.

Q: Updates not applying

Section titled “Q: Updates not applying”

A: For Options 1-4 and 6, restart Claude. For Option 5, run git pull && npm run setup.

Section titled “Automatic (Recommended)”

Section titled “Manual”

Beads: A Memory Upgrade for Your AI Coding Agent

Dec 22, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Introduction

Section titled “Introduction”

Beads (bd) is a distributed, git-backed graph issue tracker designed specifically for AI coding agents. Created by Steve Yegge (former Google/Amazon engineer and renowned software blogger), Beads solves one of the most frustrating problems in AI-assisted development: the context window limitation.

When you start a new session with your AI coding assistant, it loses all understanding of your project goals and progress. Beads provides a persistent, structured memory that replaces messy markdown plans with a dependency-aware graph, allowing agents to handle long-horizon tasks without losing context.

Key Highlights

Section titled “Key Highlights”
  • Git as Database: Issues stored as JSONL in .beads/, versioned and merged like code
  • Agent-Optimized: JSON output, dependency tracking, and auto-ready task detection
  • Zero Conflict: Hash-based IDs prevent merge collisions in multi-agent workflows
  • Invisible Infrastructure: SQLite local cache with background daemon for auto-sync
  • Memory Compaction: Semantic summarization of old tasks to save context window

Prerequisites

Section titled “Prerequisites”

Before installing Beads, ensure you have:

  • Operating System: Linux (glibc 2.32+), macOS, or Windows 11
  • Git: Version control system (for syncing and collaboration)
  • Go 1.24+ (optional, for building from source)

Alpha Software Warning

Section titled “Alpha Software Warning”

  • Avoid using in critical production systems until 1.0 release
  • Back up important data regularly
  • Report issues on GitHub

Git Dependency

Beads relies entirely on Git for synchronization:

  • Ensure git push completes successfully before ending sessions
  • The “plane has NOT landed until git push completes”

Context Window Consideration

Section titled “Context Window Consideration”

While Beads reduces context consumption, complex queries can still use significant tokens. Use targeted queries (bd ready) rather than full dumps.

FAQ

Section titled “FAQ”

Q: How is Beads different from GitHub Issues?

Section titled “Q: How is Beads different from GitHub Issues?”

A: Beads offers:

  • Typed dependencies with semantic meaning
  • Offline-first design with local SQLite
  • Git-native sync without external services
  • Hash-based IDs preventing multi-agent collisions
  • Agent-optimized output (JSON format)

Q: Can I use Beads offline?

Section titled “Q: Can I use Beads offline?”

A: Yes! All queries run against local SQLite. Sync happens via git push/pull when network is available.

Q: What about existing issue trackers?

Section titled “Q: What about existing issue trackers?”

A: Beads complements rather than replaces tools like Jira or GitHub Issues. Use Beads for AI agent memory and local development; sync important issues to your main tracker.

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

Beads represents a paradigm shift in how we think about AI coding assistants. Instead of treating them as stateless tools that forget everything between sessions, Beads gives them persistent, structured memory that grows with your project.

By leveraging Git’s familiar workflow, providing agent-optimized queries, and implementing intelligent memory compaction, Beads enables truly long-horizon task management. Whether you’re working solo or coordinating multiple AI agents, Beads ensures your coding assistants never lose track of the bigger picture.

Claude Code System Prompts Revealed: Inside the AI That Powers Your Coding

Dec 21, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Discover the Hidden Architecture Behind Anthropic’s AI Coding Assistant

The Discovery

Section titled “The Discovery”

Ever wondered what makes Claude Code tick? Thanks to the open-source community, specifically the Piebald-AI/claude-code-system-prompts repository, we now have unprecedented visibility into the intricate system prompts that power one of the most popular AI coding assistants on the market.

This repository, maintained by the team behind Piebald, provides a comprehensive breakdown of all Claude Code’s various system prompts, updated with each new version. As of Claude Code v2.0.75 (December 20th, 2025), it covers 56 versions of changelog since v2.0.14.

Why Claude Code Has Multiple System Prompts

Section titled “Why Claude Code Has Multiple System Prompts”

Claude Code doesn’t just have one single string for its system prompt. Instead, there are multiple components working together:

Component TypeDescription
Conditional PromptsLarge portions added depending on environment and configs
Tool DescriptionsBuiltin tools like Write, Bash, and TodoWrite
Agent PromptsSeparate system prompts for Explore, Plan, and Task agents
Utility FunctionsAI-powered features like conversation compaction, CLAUDE.md generation

The result is 40+ strings that are constantly changing and moving within a very large minified JS file.

Key Prompt Categories

Section titled “Key Prompt Categories”

1. Main System Prompt (2,981 tokens)

Section titled “1. Main System Prompt (2,981 tokens)”

The core system prompt defines Claude Code’s fundamental behavior:

Communication Style:

  • Responses should be “short and concise” for command-line display
  • Uses GitHub-flavored markdown formatted for monospace fonts
  • Avoids emojis unless explicitly requested
  • Tools are for task completion only, not user communication

Technical Approach:

  • Prioritizes technical accuracy and truthfulness
  • Provides direct, objective technical info
  • Reads files before proposing modifications
  • Avoids over-engineering and unnecessary abstractions

Section titled “2. Agent Prompts”

A2UI: Google's Agent-Driven Interface Protocol That Changes Everything

Dec 21, 2025
Vibe Sparking

From Text-Only Responses to Rich, Native UIs: How Google’s A2UI Protocol Enables AI Agents to Generate Interactive Interfaces

1. Introduction: Features and Highlights

Section titled “1. Introduction: Features and Highlights”

What is A2UI?

Section titled “What is A2UI?”

On December 15, 2025, Google publicly launched A2UI (Agent to UI), an open-source protocol that enables AI agents to generate rich, interactive user interfaces that render natively across platforms—without executing arbitrary code.

Think about it: instead of an AI agent responding with just text, it can now send back a complete, interactive form, a data visualization card, or a booking confirmation interface. The magic? Your app renders these UIs using native components, maintaining your design system while benefiting from AI-generated interfaces.

Core Problem Solved

Section titled “Core Problem Solved”

Traditional agent interactions face a fundamental tension:

ApproachProblem
Text-only responsesLimited expressiveness, tedious back-and-forth
HTML/JavaScript in iframesSecurity risks, sandboxing complexity, no native styling
A2UI approachDeclarative JSON data + native rendering = best of both worlds

Key Features

Section titled “Key Features”
FeatureDescription
Security-FirstDeclarative data format (not executable code). Agents can only render pre-approved components from your catalog
LLM-FriendlyFlat component lists with ID references, easy for LLMs to generate incrementally
Framework-AgnosticWorks with React, Flutter, Angular, SwiftUI, Lit, and more
Transport-AgnosticCompatible with A2A, AG-UI, REST (experimental)
Progressive RenderingUsers see UI building in real-time as LLMs generate

Who’s Behind It?

Section titled “Who’s Behind It?”
  • Core Team: Google A2UI Team
  • Key Partners: CopilotKit/AG-UI (day-zero compatibility), Opal (core contributor), Gemini Enterprise
  • License: Apache 2.0
  • Current Version: v0.8 (Public Preview)

2. Prerequisites, Installation and Configuration

Section titled “2. Prerequisites, Installation and Configuration”

Prerequisites

Section titled “Prerequisites”

Before getting started, ensure you have:

  • Node.js (for web clients and renderers)
  • Python 3.8+ (for agent samples)
  • Gemini API Key (for demo agents)
  • UV package manager (recommended for Python)

4. Precautions, FAQ, and Troubleshooting

Section titled “4. Precautions, FAQ, and Troubleshooting”

Important Precautions

Section titled “Important Precautions”
AreaRecommendation
SecurityOnly include components in your catalog that you trust. A2UI is declarative, not executable, but your renderer implementations must be secure
VersioningA2UI is v0.8 (Public Preview). Expect breaking changes before v1.0
PerformanceFor complex UIs, consider pagination and lazy loading in your renderer
AccessibilityYour renderer is responsible for accessibility. A2UI provides structure; you provide semantics

FAQ

Section titled “FAQ”

Q: How is A2UI different from sending HTML?

A: A2UI sends structured JSON that describes UI components. Your app renders these using native widgets, maintaining your design system, accessibility, and security. HTML/JS requires sandboxing and can’t integrate with native styling.

Q: Can agents execute arbitrary code through A2UI?

A: No. A2UI is a declarative data format. Agents can only request components from your pre-approved catalog. Your renderer decides how to present them.

Q: Does A2UI replace MCP (Model Context Protocol)?

A: No, they’re complementary. MCP connects agents to tools and data. A2UI defines how agents describe UIs. You can use both in the same system.

Q: What about AG-UI?

A: AG-UI is the transport layer for real-time agent-UI communication. A2UI defines the payload format. They work together beautifully.

Q: Is A2UI production-ready?

A: A2UI is v0.8 (Public Preview). It’s functional but evolving. Production use should plan for specification updates.

Troubleshooting

Section titled “Troubleshooting”

Problem: Agent responses not rendering

Solution: Ensure your agent’s output matches the A2UI schema with proper delimiters.

Problem: Components not appearing

Solution: Verify the component type is in your catalog:

Problem: Data binding not updating

Solution: Check that your data model is properly initialized and the bind paths are correct:

5. Collaboration with Similar Products and Comparative Analysis

Section titled “5. Collaboration with Similar Products and Comparative Analysis”

The Agentic UI Protocol Landscape

Section titled “The Agentic UI Protocol Landscape”

In 2025, three complementary protocols have emerged as the foundation for agent-driven interfaces:

ProtocolPurposeCreatorFocus
A2UIDeclarative UI descriptionsGoogleWhat UI to render (payload)
MCPAgent-to-tool connectionsAnthropicHow agents access tools (vertical)
AG-UIReal-time agent-UI communicationCopilotKitHow UIs receive updates (transport)
A2AAgent-to-agent communicationGoogleHow agents talk to each other (horizontal)

A2UI vs MCP-UI Comparison

Section titled “A2UI vs MCP-UI Comparison”
AspectA2UIMCP-UI/MCP Apps
PhilosophyNative-first: “Blueprint” for native componentsWeb-first: HTML/JS in sandboxed iframes
RenderingApp renders using native widgetsBrowser renders sandboxed web content
StylingInherits host app stylingIsolated styling in sandbox
Security ModelComponent catalog restrictionIframe sandboxing
Cross-PlatformSame payload works on web, mobile, desktopPrimarily web-focused
Backed ByGoogleAnthropic, OpenAI

How They Work Together

Section titled “How They Work Together”

Comparative Analysis with Opal

Section titled “Comparative Analysis with Opal”

Opal (also from Google) uses A2UI as its underlying protocol:

  • Opal provides higher-level abstractions for AI mini-apps
  • A2UI provides the wire protocol for UI descriptions
  • Together they enable “one-sentence AI apps”

When to Use What

ScenarioRecommended Protocol

Web chat with rich responsesMCP Apps or A2UI
Multi-agent orchestration with UIA2UI + A2A + AG-UI
Tool-calling with data accessMCP
Cross-platform consistencyA2UI

Roadmap

Section titled “Roadmap”

The A2UI team has prioritized:

  1. Specification stabilization (v1.0)
  2. React renderer (official support)
  3. Jetpack Compose and SwiftUI (native mobile)
  4. REST transport (production-ready)
  5. Integration with Genkit and LangGraph

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

A2UI represents a fundamental shift in how AI agents interact with users. Instead of text-only responses or risky code execution, agents can now describe rich, interactive UIs that render natively across platforms.

Key Takeaways:

  1. A2UI is declarative - It describes UIs, not executes code
  2. Security by design - Component catalog restricts what agents can request
  3. Framework-agnostic - One agent response works across web, mobile, desktop
  4. Composable - Works alongside MCP, AG-UI, and A2A for complete agent systems

As the agentic era accelerates, protocols like A2UI will become essential infrastructure for building AI applications that feel native, secure, and responsive.

Ready to build with A2UI? Start with the official quickstart or explore the GitHub samples.

What Are Hugging Face Skills?

Section titled “What Are Hugging Face Skills?”

Hugging Face Skills is a revolutionary system that enables AI coding agents like Claude Code, OpenAI Codex, and Google Gemini CLI to fine-tune open-source language models end-to-end through natural language conversations.

Instead of writing complex training scripts, configuring GPU resources, and managing deployment pipelines manually, you simply describe what you want in plain English:

The AI agent handles everything else: data validation, hardware selection, script generation, job submission, progress monitoring, and model publishing.

Real-time MonitoringTracks progress via Trackio dashboard

What is n8n-skills?

Section titled “What is n8n-skills?”

n8n-skills is a collection of 7 complementary Claude Code skills designed to teach AI assistants how to build production-ready n8n workflows using the n8n-mcp MCP server.

Created by Romuald Członkowski from AI Advisors, these skills solve the common challenges developers face when building n8n workflows programmatically.

Why n8n-skills Exists

Section titled “Why n8n-skills Exists”

Building n8n workflows programmatically can be challenging. Common issues include:

ChallengeHow n8n-skills Helps
Using MCP tools incorrectlyExpert guidance on tool selection
Validation error loopsValidation error interpretation and fixing
Unknown workflow patterns5 proven architectural patterns
Node misconfigurationOperation-aware node configuration
Expression syntax errorsCorrect {{}} patterns and variables

The 7 Skills

Section titled “The 7 Skills”

1. n8n Expression Syntax

Section titled “1. n8n Expression Syntax”

Teaches correct n8n expression syntax and common patterns.

Activates when: Writing expressions, using {{}} syntax, accessing $json/$node variables.

Key Features:

  • Core variables ($json, $node, $now, $env)
  • Critical gotcha: Webhook data is under $json.body
  • Common mistakes catalog with fixes
  • When NOT to use expressions (Code nodes!)

2. n8n MCP Tools Expert (HIGHEST PRIORITY)

Section titled “2. n8n MCP Tools Expert (HIGHEST PRIORITY)”

Expert guide for using n8n-mcp MCP tools effectively.

Key Features:

  • Tool selection guide (which tool for which task)
  • nodeType format differences (nodes-base.* vs n8n-nodes-base.*)
  • Validation profiles (minimal/runtime/ai-friendly/strict)
  • Smart parameters (branch=“true” for IF nodes)
  • Auto-sanitization system explained

3. n8n Workflow Patterns

Section titled “3. n8n Workflow Patterns”

Build workflows using 5 proven architectural patterns.

Key Features:

  • 5 proven patterns (webhook processing, HTTP API, database, AI, scheduled)
  • Workflow creation checklist
  • Real examples from 2,653+ n8n templates
  • Pattern selection guide

4. n8n Validation Expert

Section titled “4. n8n Validation Expert”

Interpret validation errors and guide fixing.

Key Features:

  • Validation loop workflow
  • Real error catalog
  • Auto-sanitization behavior explained
  • False positives guide

5. n8n Node Configuration

Section titled “5. n8n Node Configuration”

Operation-aware node configuration guidance.

Key Features:

  • Property dependency rules (e.g., sendBody → contentType)
  • Operation-specific requirements
  • AI connection types (8 types for AI Agent workflows)

6. n8n Code JavaScript

Section titled “6. n8n Code JavaScript”

Write effective JavaScript code in n8n Code nodes.

Key Features:

  • Data access patterns ($input.all(), $input.first(), $input.item)
  • Correct return format: [{json: {...}}]
  • Built-in functions ($helpers.httpRequest(), DateTime, $jmespath())
  • Top 5 error patterns with solutions (covering 62%+ of failures)
  • 10 production-tested patterns

7. n8n Code Python

Section titled “7. n8n Code Python”

Write Python code in n8n Code nodes with proper limitations awareness.

Key Features:

  • Important: Use JavaScript for 95% of use cases
  • Critical limitation: No external libraries (requests, pandas, numpy)
  • Standard library reference (json, datetime, re, etc.)
  • Workarounds for missing libraries

FAQs & Troubleshooting

Section titled “FAQs & Troubleshooting”

Q: Why does my webhook workflow fail?

Section titled “Q: Why does my webhook workflow fail?”

A: Remember that webhook data is under $json.body, not directly in $json. This is the most common gotcha.

Q: How do I choose between Code node JS vs Python?

Section titled “Q: How do I choose between Code node JS vs Python?”

A: Use JavaScript for 95% of use cases. Python has critical limitations:

  • No external libraries (requests, pandas, numpy)
  • Only standard library available

Q: Validation keeps failing with false positives

Section titled “Q: Validation keeps failing with false positives”

A: Use appropriate validation profiles:

  • minimal for quick checks during development
  • runtime for production-ready validation
  • Check the auto-sanitization behavior

Q: Which MCP tools should I use first?

Section titled “Q: Which MCP tools should I use first?”

A: Follow this order:

  1. search_templates - Check if templates exist
  2. search_nodes - Find required nodes
  3. get_node - Get configuration details
  4. validate_node - Validate your config
  5. validate_workflow - Final check

Gemini CLI Conductor: Context-Driven Development That Plans Before It Codes

Dec 21, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Introduction

Section titled “Introduction”

Benjamin Franklin once said: “Failing to plan is planning to fail.”

This wisdom applies perfectly to AI-assisted coding. While tools like ChatGPT and Claude excel at answering questions, they often fall short when it comes to complex, multi-session projects where context gets lost between conversations.

Enter Conductor - a game-changing extension for Gemini CLI that introduces Context-Driven Development. Instead of treating AI interactions as fleeting chat logs, Conductor helps you create formal specifications and plans that live alongside your code as persistent Markdown files.

What is Conductor?

Section titled “What is Conductor?”

Conductor is a preview extension for Gemini CLI that transforms how you work with AI on code projects. Its core philosophy is simple but powerful:

“Treat context as a managed artifact alongside your code.”

Rather than depending on impermanent chat logs, Conductor helps you:

  • Create formal specifications before writing code
  • Maintain persistent context across sessions
  • Build implementation plans that guide the AI’s behavior
  • Keep your repository as the single source of truth

Key Features

Section titled “Key Features”

1. Plan Before Implementation

Section titled “1. Plan Before Implementation”

Conductor enforces a structured workflow: Context → Spec & Plan → Implement. This ensures you think through requirements before diving into code.

2. Persistent Context Files

Section titled “2. Persistent Context Files”

All project context is stored in Markdown files that:

  • Survive beyond individual chat sessions
  • Can be version-controlled with Git
  • Enable team collaboration with shared standards

3. Hierarchical Task Organization

Section titled “3. Hierarchical Task Organization”

Work is organized into a clear hierarchy:

  • Tracks - High-level work units (features, bug fixes)
  • Phases - Major stages within a track
  • Tasks - Individual implementation steps

4. Brownfield-Friendly

Section titled “4. Brownfield-Friendly”

Unlike many AI tools that struggle with existing codebases, Conductor excels at “brownfield” development - working with mature projects where architectural nuance matters.

Installation

Section titled “Installation”

Getting started with Conductor is straightforward:

The --auto-update flag ensures you always have the latest version.

Prerequisites:

  • Gemini CLI installed and configured
  • Git repository initialized
  • Node.js (for Gemini CLI)

Commands Reference

Section titled “Commands Reference”

Conductor provides five core commands:

CommandPurpose
/conductor:setupInitial project configuration (run once per project)
/conductor:newTrackBegin a new feature or bug fix
/conductor:implementExecute planned tasks
/conductor:statusView current progress
/conductor:revertUndo work logically (tracks/phases/tasks, not commits)

Pro Tip: Add a description to newTrack: /conductor:newTrack "Add user authentication"

The Context-Driven Workflow

Section titled “The Context-Driven Workflow”

Step 1: Setup Your Project

Section titled “Step 1: Setup Your Project”

Run /conductor:setup to establish your project’s foundational context:

This creates configuration files for:

  • Product Definition - Users, goals, features
  • Tech Stack - Languages, frameworks, databases
  • Workflow Preferences - TDD approach, commit strategies
  • Code Style Guides - Formatting, naming conventions

Step 2: Create a New Track

Section titled “Step 2: Create a New Track”

When starting new work, create a track:

This generates:

  • spec.md - Detailed requirements document
  • plan.md - Actionable task breakdown with phases

Step 3: Review Before Implementation

Section titled “Step 3: Review Before Implementation”

Critical: Conductor requires human review of plans before implementation begins. This is your chance to refine requirements and catch issues early.

Step 4: Implement

Section titled “Step 4: Implement”

Execute the plan:

Conductor will work through tasks systematically, maintaining state so you can pause and resume across sessions.

Generated File Structure

Section titled “Generated File Structure”

After setup, your project will include:

Best Practices

Section titled “Best Practices”

1. Run Setup Once Per Project

Section titled “1. Run Setup Once Per Project”

The setup command establishes shared team standards. Run it once, then commit the generated files.

2. Review Plans Carefully

Section titled “2. Review Plans Carefully”

Plans require human approval before implementation. Take time to refine them - it’s much cheaper to fix a plan than to refactor code.

3. Monitor Token Usage

Section titled “3. Monitor Token Usage”

Context-heavy operations consume more tokens. Use /stats model to track consumption.

4. Use Logical Revert

Section titled “4. Use Logical Revert”

The /conductor:revert command reverts based on tracks/phases/tasks rather than Git commits, providing safer rollbacks.

5. Maintain Context Files as Living Documentation

Section titled “5. Maintain Context Files as Living Documentation”

Your conductor files aren’t just for AI - they’re valuable documentation for your team.

Conductor vs. Other AI Tools

Section titled “Conductor vs. Other AI Tools”
FeatureStandard Chat AIConductor
Context PersistenceSession-onlyPermanent files
PlanningOptionalEnforced
Team CollaborationCopy-paste chaosShared configs
Brownfield SupportLimitedExcellent
State ManagementNoneBuilt-in checkpoints

vs. Amazon Q Developer Transform

Section titled “vs. Amazon Q Developer Transform”

While both are AI-powered, they serve different purposes:

  • Conductor = Project manager for day-to-day coding
  • Amazon Transform = Large-scale migrations (e.g., Java 8 → Java 17)

vs. Cursor/Claude Code

Section titled “vs. Cursor/Claude Code”

Conductor complements rather than replaces IDE-integrated AI:

  • Use Conductor for planning and specification
  • Use Cursor/Claude for in-editor implementation

Real-World Scenarios

Section titled “Real-World Scenarios”

Scenario 1: New Feature Development

Section titled “Scenario 1: New Feature Development”

Scenario 2: Bug Fix with Investigation

Section titled “Scenario 2: Bug Fix with Investigation”

Scenario 3: Team Onboarding

Section titled “Scenario 3: Team Onboarding”

New developer joins? They can:

  1. Read conductor/product.md for product context
  2. Review conductor/tech-stack.md for technical decisions
  3. Check conductor/workflow.md for conventions
  4. Start contributing immediately with consistent guidelines

Troubleshooting

Section titled “Troubleshooting”
IssueSolution
Extension not foundEnsure Gemini CLI is updated to latest version
Setup failsCheck you have write permissions in the repository
Context too largeUse /stats model to monitor; consider splitting work

FAQ

Section titled “FAQ”

Q: Does Conductor work with existing projects?

Section titled “Q: Does Conductor work with existing projects?”

A: Yes! Conductor is specifically designed for “brownfield” development. The setup command analyzes your existing codebase to understand patterns.

Q: Can I edit generated plans?

Section titled “Q: Can I edit generated plans?”

A: Absolutely. Plans are Markdown files - edit them as needed before implementation.

Q: Is my code sent to Google?

Section titled “Q: Is my code sent to Google?”

A: Conductor uses Gemini API. Review Google’s AI terms and your organization’s policies.

Q: Can I use Conductor with other AI tools?

Section titled “Q: Can I use Conductor with other AI tools?”

A: Yes. The generated specs and plans are valuable input for any AI assistant.

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

Conductor represents a paradigm shift in AI-assisted development. By treating context as a first-class artifact and planning as a mandatory step, it addresses the core weakness of chat-based AI coding: loss of context and lack of structure.

Key takeaways:

  • Plan first, code second - Conductor enforces specification before implementation
  • Context is king - Persistent files ensure nothing gets lost between sessions
  • Team-ready - Shared configurations enable consistent AI interactions across developers
  • Brownfield-capable - Works with your existing codebase, not against it

The future of AI coding isn’t just about generating code faster - it’s about generating the right code, consistently. Conductor is a significant step in that direction.

BMAD Installation & Configuration Guide: Best Practices for Project-Level Setup

Dec 20, 2025
Vibe Sparking

BMAD (Build More, Architect Dreams) is an AI-driven agile development methodology framework that integrates multiple AI Agents, workflows, and modules. It supports 18+ IDEs including Claude Code, Codex, and Cursor. This guide walks you through the complete installation and configuration process for BMAD v6.0.0-alpha.

1 | Why Project-Level Installation?

Section titled “1 | Why Project-Level Installation?”

Key Recommendation: Install BMAD in your project directory, NOT in your user home directory.

Benefits:

  • Isolation: Each project has independent BMAD configuration
  • Version Control: Project-level config can be tracked with Git
  • Team Collaboration: Team members get identical configs when cloning
  • Multi-Project Support: Different projects can use different BMAD versions

Post-installation directory structure:

The .bmad configuration directory contains these submodules:

2 | Prerequisites

Section titled “2 | Prerequisites”

Ensure you have:

  • Node.js (v18+ recommended)
  • Bun or npm/npx
  • Claude Code or another supported IDE
